newsitem.title: UK: IPE Brent ends weak after posting new 12-month low.
newsitem.headline: IPE Brent ends weak after posting new 12-month low.

text.p: IPE Brent crude dipped in late trade to a 12-month low as an early bounce evaporated amid talk of rising U.S. product stocks, dealers said.
July Brent closed down 6 cents at $17.50 a barrel, the lowest seen on the prompt contract since May 1996, extending a $2-slide since the beginning of June.
"It dropped to new lows but the market was very thin below $17.50," said a broker.
Brent bounced early after managing to hold key support at $17.54 on Monday but lost ground ahead of the release of American Petroleum Institute (API) inventory data.
"Everything was looking oversold so a correction was due but then a few pre-API jitters set in," said a broker.
"We saw some strength when New York opened but then that died away," said another broker.
Rising U.S. crude and gasoline stocks gave investment funds an excuse to bale out of the market last Friday and this week's API figures could again set short-term market direction.
Refinery runs are expected to remain at or near record levels in Tuesday's API report, leading to a rise in distillate and gasoline stocks, according to a survey by Reuters.

Distillate stocks are expected to show a rise of 2.5 million barrels in the week to June 6. The build in gasoline should be more modest at around one million barrels, according to the analysts surveyed.
Earlier, IPE June gas oil closed $1.50 firmer at $161.50 a tonne.
